metadata.title: Week 1: Network Fundamentals - Formative Assessment
metadata.description: Computer Networks formative quiz covering network fundamentals, TCP/IP, Docker and Wireshark
metadata.author: ing. dr. Antonio Clim

learning_objectives.description: Measure and interpret network latency using ICMP ping
Parse and process network data from various formats
Capture and analyse network traffic using standard tools
Calculate transmission delays for different network scenarios
Configure and manage Docker containers for network labs
Use Wireshark to capture and filter network traffic

question_banks.name: Pre-Lab Quick Check
question_banks.description: Answer these BEFORE starting the laboratory exercises

question_banks.name: During-Lab Checkpoints
question_banks.description: Verify understanding at key points during the lab

question_banks.name: Full Review
question_banks.description: Additional questions covering all learning objectives

questions.stem: What is the difference between latency and bandwidth?

options.text: Latency = data volume; Bandwidth = time delay
Latency = time delay; Bandwidth = data volume per second
They are the same thing measured differently
Latency is for TCP; Bandwidth is for UDP

questions.explanation: Latency measures TIME (milliseconds) - how long a packet takes to travel. Bandwidth measures THROUGHPUT (Mbps) - how much data flows per second.

questions.stem: The command to show IP addresses in Linux is: ip ___
questions.explanation: 'ip addr' or 'ip a' displays all network interfaces with their IP addresses

questions.stem: What does the LISTEN socket state mean?

options.text: The socket is actively transferring data
The socket is waiting for incoming connections
The socket has encountered an error
The socket is in the process of closing

questions.explanation: LISTEN means a server socket is ready and waiting for clients to connect.

questions.stem: In Docker, what is the difference between an image and a container?

options.text: Image = running instance; Container = read-only template
Image = read-only template; Container = running instance
They are the same thing with different names
Images are for Windows; Containers are for Linux

questions.explanation: Image = Read-only template (like a class in programming). Container = Running instance of an image (like an object).

questions.stem: What port does Portainer use by default in our lab environment?
questions.explanation: Portainer runs on port 9000 (http://localhost:9000). This port is RESERVED!

questions.stem: A ping to localhost (127.0.0.1) travels through the physical network interface.
questions.explanation: Loopback traffic (127.0.0.1) never leaves the machine. It uses the virtual loopback interface (lo).

questions.stem: In the TCP three-way handshake, what flag combination does the server send in response to a SYN?

options.text: ACK only
SYN only
SYN and ACK (SYN-ACK)
FIN and ACK

questions.explanation: The three-way handshake sequence: 1. Client sends SYN, 2. Server responds with SYN-ACK, 3. Client sends ACK.

questions.stem: Why does TCP use sequence numbers?

options.text: To encrypt the data
To identify the sender
To ensure ordered delivery and detect missing segments
To compress the payload

questions.explanation: Sequence numbers allow TCP to reassemble segments in correct order, detect missing segments and calculate round-trip time.

questions.stem: To see ALL containers (including stopped ones), use: docker ps ___
questions.explanation: 'docker ps' shows only running containers. 'docker ps -a' shows all containers including stopped ones.

questions.stem: If a process inside a Docker container connects to 'localhost', where does it connect?

options.text: The Windows host machine
The WSL2 virtual machine
The container's own loopback interface
The Docker host network

questions.explanation: Each container has its own network namespace with its own loopback interface.

questions.stem: To ping google.com exactly 4 times in Linux, the command is: ping ___ 4 google.com
questions.explanation: The -c flag specifies the count of ICMP echo requests to send.

questions.stem: You see 'Connection refused' when trying to connect to a server. What is the most likely cause?

options.text: The network cable is unplugged
The firewall is blocking the connection
No process is listening on that port
The server is too busy to accept connections

questions.explanation: 'Connection refused' means the TCP stack received the SYN packet and responded with RST because nothing is listening.

questions.stem: Order these commands to correctly start a lab environment:
questions.explanation: 1. Start Docker service, 2. Navigate to lab directory, 3. Start containers, 4. Verify containers running

questions.stem: A TCP connection shows state TIME_WAIT. What does this indicate?

options.text: The connection is waiting for the initial handshake
The connection is waiting for data from the peer
The connection was closed and is waiting before reusing the port
The connection has timed out due to network issues

questions.explanation: TIME_WAIT occurs after a connection is closed. The socket remains in this state for 2*MSL.

questions.stem: In Wireshark, which filter shows only TCP packets with the SYN flag set?

options.text: tcp.syn
tcp.flags.syn == 1
tcp contains SYN
filter.tcp.syn

questions.explanation: tcp.flags.syn == 1 filters packets where the SYN flag is set (value 1).

questions.stem: When parsing a CSV file with network data, which Python module is most appropriate for handling comma-separated values with proper quoting?

options.text: The re module with regex patterns
The csv module from the standard library
The json module with custom parsing
The str.split(',') method directly

questions.explanation: The csv module handles edge cases like quoted fields containing commas and escaped quotes.

questions.stem: To extract an IP address from a string using Python regex, each octet pattern is: \d{1,_}
questions.explanation: Each octet of an IPv4 address is 1-3 digits (0-255). The pattern \d{1,3} matches this.

questions.stem: Calculate the transmission delay (in milliseconds) for sending a 1500-byte packet over a 100 Mbps link. Round to 2 decimal places.
questions.explanation: Transmission delay = (1500 bytes x 8 bits/byte) / (100 x 10^6 bits/second) = 0.12 ms

questions.stem: Which component of end-to-end delay is affected by the LENGTH of the physical link?

options.text: Transmission delay
Propagation delay
Processing delay
Queuing delay

questions.explanation: Propagation delay = Distance / Speed of light in medium. Longer links increase propagation delay.

questions.stem: In Wireshark, which interface should you select to capture traffic from Docker containers running in WSL2?

options.text: Ethernet (physical adapter)
Wi-Fi (wireless adapter)
vEthernet (WSL)
Loopback Adapter

questions.explanation: Docker containers in WSL2 communicate through the virtual Ethernet adapter vEthernet (WSL).

questions.stem: To filter Wireshark display to show only TCP packets on port 9090, you would type: tcp.port == _____
questions.explanation: tcp.port matches both source and destination port.

questions.stem: When analysing a PCAP file, you see a packet sequence: SYN, SYN-ACK, RST. What does this indicate?

options.text: Successful connection followed by graceful close
Connection refused - server rejected the connection
Connection timeout - no response from server
Packet corruption - invalid checksum detected

questions.explanation: RST (Reset) after SYN-ACK typically indicates the destination port is closed or a firewall is blocking the connection.
